awd_titl_txt: CSR: Small: Human-Centered Synthesis of Provably Correct Controllers for Hybrid Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Hybrid systems are a mathematical framework that has been widely used to model engineering and natural systems whose dynamics have both continuous and discrete aspects. Applications range from modern "fly-by-wire" airplanes to cellular biology. A controller for a hybrid system observes the execution of the system and issues input signals and/or trigger events in the hybrid system so as to meet the system's goals and safety requirements.  An outstanding problem is that for complex hybrid systems existing methods for controller synthesis require exceedingly large computational resources.

This project seeks to address the high computational demands of constructing controllers for hybrid systems in a new way. The novelty of the approach lies in using human-centered computing (crowdsourcing), while ensuring that the obtained controller is correct. The expected outcomes of this project are mathematical theory and algorithms that will enable the idea above for a wide range of problems, including those involving nonlinear systems and random events. These results are further implemented in simulator computer games, which will be deployed online.  The amount of computing resource that can be potentially be harvested through crowdsourcing is very high. Earlier crowdsourcing applications such as reCAPTCHA, FoldIt, and Wikipedia have recorded billions of hours of effort by their human contributors. Beyond solving the controller synthesis problem, the outcomes of this project can lead to new ways to tap into this resource for solving new problems.

The broader impacts of this  project include improvements in the safety of a wide range of engineered systems.  The project also has an educational outreach program involving K-12 students and educators in cutting edge multidisciplinary research. Uniquely, the gaming theme is an ideal vehicle to engage pre-college students in science and engineering.

por.por_cntn:
Hybrid systems are a mathematical framework that has been widely used to model engineering and natural systems, whose dynamics have both continuous and discrete aspects. Their applications range from cellular biology, embedded control systems, to fly-by-wire modern airplanes. A controller for a hybrid system observes the execution of the system and issues input signals and/or trigger some events in the system so as to meet the system’s goal and safety requirements.  For complex systems, existing methods for controller synthesis require exceedingly large computational resources.

This project is concerned with constructing controllers for hybrid systems. The novelty of the approach lies in the use of human inputs in to design the controllers. Our approach is based on the idea of establishing the robustness of execution trajectories, such that a provably correct controller can be synthesized using finitely many valid execution trajectories. In our framework, these valid trajectories can be obtained from human played computer games that simulate the hybrid systems.

 

Intellectual merits: As outcomes of this project, we developed theories and methods for:

  1. Performing synthesis for provably correct controllers for hybrid systems with nonlinear dynamics. In particular, we showed that for nonlinear dynamics that are feedback linearizable or differentially flat, the robustness property that is mentioned above can be derived/proven in an automated fashion.
  2. Synthesizing not-only provably correct, but also optimal controller. To do so, we develop a functional gradient based method to calculate the optimal control input. As a byproduct of this theory, we can also use the same mathematical tool in verification of systems with inputs. In this case, instead of the optimal input we search for an input that falsifies the correctness property of the system.
  3. Synthesizing provably correct feedback controller. All the results above involve feed-forward controllers. To make the performance of the control system more robust to disturbances, we developed a method to synthesize a feedback controller, based on the obtained valid execution trajectories. The synthesis is performed in such a way that the obtained feedback controller is also provably correct.

 

Broader impacts: Research outcomes from this project have been disseminated as peer-reviewed scientific publications, in addition to one book chapter and numerous seminars. This project partially supported 4 doctoral students and 3 undergraduate students during the course of its execution. Beyond the planned impact area, results from this project also manifested in areas such as safe controller design for robotics systems.

Modified by: Anak Agung Julius
